title: Medical Definition of Vaccination
author: Medical Editor Melissa Conrad Stöppler; MD
cleaned_text: order to stimulate the [immune system](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=3907) against the microbe, thereby preventing [disease](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=3011). Vaccinations, or immunizations, work by stimulating the [immune](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=3905) system, the natural disease-fighting system of the body. The [healthy](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=39755) immune system is able to recognize invading [bacteria](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=13954) and [viruses](https://www.rxlist.com/viral_infections_slideshow_pictures/article.htm) and produce substances (antibodies) to destroy or disable them. Immunizations prepare the immune system to ward off a disease. To immunize against [viral](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=15037) diseases, the [virus](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=5997) used in the vaccine has been weakened or killed. To only immunize against [bacterial](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=15038) diseases, it is generally possible to use a small portion of the dead bacteria to stimulate the formation of antibodies against the whole bacteria. In addition to the initial [immunization](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=3909) [process](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=5054), it has been found that the effectiveness of immunizations can be improved by periodic [repeat](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=25471) injections or "boosters."
